questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : FINANCIAL FORENSICS (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1: A company is facing a lawsuit from a customer. It is possible, but not probable, that the company will have to pay a settlement that management estimates to be ₹3,000,000. How would this fact be reported in the financial statements to be issued at the end of the current month?
question_texts: A company is facing a lawsuit from a customer. It is possible, but not probable, that the company will have to pay a settlement that management estimates to be ₹3,000,000. How would this fact be reported in the financial statements to be issued at the end of the current month?

options.option_text: None because disclosure is not required
In a descriptive narrative in the footnote section

questions.question_text_1: Total cash inflow in the operating section of the statement of cash flows should include which of the following?
question_texts: Total cash inflow in the operating section of the statement of cash flows should include which of the following?

options.option_text: Cash received from customers at the point of sale
Cash collections from customer accounts receivable
Cash received in advance of revenue recognition (unearned revenue)

options.option_text: Cannot be determined without additional information

questions.question_text_1: You have observed that the net profit margin ratio for a retail chain has increased steadily over the last three years. The most likely explanation is which of the following?
question_texts: You have observed that the net profit margin ratio for a retail chain has increased steadily over the last three years. The most likely explanation is which of the following?

options.option_text: New stores were added throughout the last three years, and sales increased asa result of the additional new locations
The company began construction of a new, larger main office location threeyears ago that was put into use at the end of the second year
Salaries for upper management as a percentage of total expenses havedecreased over the last three years
A successful advertising campaign increased sales companywide, but with noincrease in the operating expenses

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is false regarding the balance sheet?
question_texts: Which of the following is false regarding the balance sheet?

options.option_text: The accounts shown on a balance sheet represent the basic accountingequation for a particular business entity
The balance sheet reports the amount of assets, liabilities, and stockholders'equity of an accounting entity at a point in time
The retained earnings balance shown on the balance sheet must agree withthe ending retained earnings balance shown on the statement of stockholders' equity
The balance sheet reports the changes in specific account balances over aperiod of time

questions.question_text_1: You have been offered a job that pays an annual salary of ₹48,000, ₹51,000, and ₹55,000 over the next three years, respectively. The offer also includes a starting bonus of ₹2,500 payable immediately. What is this offer worth to you today at a discount rate of 6.5 percent?
question_texts: You have been offered a job that pays an annual salary of ₹48,000, ₹51,000, and ₹55,000 over the next three years, respectively. The offer also includes a starting bonus of ₹2,500 payable immediately. What is this offer worth to you today at a discount rate of 6.5 percent?

questions.question_text_1: Wilson's Market is considering two mutually exclusive projects that will not be repeated. The required rate of return is 13.9 percent for Project A and 12.5 percent for Project B. Project A has an initial cost of ₹54,500, and should produce cash inflows of ₹16,400, ₹28,900, and ₹31,700 for Years 1 to 3, respectively. Project B has an initial cost of ₹69,400, and should produce cash inflows of ₹0, ₹48,300, and ₹42,100, for Years 1 to 3, respectively. Which project, or projects, if either, should be accepted and why?
question_texts: Wilson's Market is considering two mutually exclusive projects that will not be repeated. The required rate of return is 13.9 percent for Project A and 12.5 percent for Project B. Project A has an initial cost of ₹54,500, and should produce cash inflows of ₹16,400, ₹28,900, and ₹31,700 for Years 1 to 3, respectively. Project B has an initial cost of ₹69,400, and should produce cash inflows of ₹0, ₹48,300, and ₹42,100, for Years 1 to 3, respectively. Which project, or projects, if either, should be accepted and why?

options.option_text: Project A; because its NPV is positive while Project B's NPV is negative
Project A; because it has the higher required rate of return
Project B; because it has the largest total cash inflow
Neither project; because neither has an NPV equal to or greater than its initialcost

Selection of an actual good customer leads to an average profit of ₹12,000. Due to misclassification, if a bad applicant is selected for loan, an average loss of ₹40,000 will be incurred. Based on the data given in the confusion matrix (Table 1), what is the overall profit?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **Financial Forensics (Computer-Based Exam)** based on the question paper, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **1. Financial Accounting & Reporting**
- **Balance Sheet**:
  - Reports assets, liabilities, and stockholders' equity at a **point in time** (not over a period).
  - Equation: **Assets = Liabilities + Stockholders' Equity**.
  - **Retained Earnings** must match the ending balance in the **Statement of Stockholders' Equity**.
  - **Contingent Liabilities**:
    - If a lawsuit is **possible but not probable**, disclose in **footnotes** (not on the balance sheet).
    - If **probable and estimable**, record as a liability.

- **Cash Flow Statement**:
  - **Operating Activities**: Includes cash from customers, collections from receivables, and unearned revenue.
  - **Investing Activities**: Purchase/sale of long-term assets (e.g., land, equipment). **Does not include inventory or short-term investments**.
  - **Financing Activities**: Not directly tested here.

- **Financial Ratios**:
  - **Return on Assets (ROA)**:
    \[
    ROA = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Average Total Assets}}
    \]
    - If **average assets increase** (with other variables constant), ROA **decreases**.
  - **Net Profit Margin**:
    \[
    \text{Net Profit Margin} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Net Sales}}
    \]
    - Increases if **sales rise without proportional expense increases** (e.g., successful advertising).

---

#### **2. Time Value of Money (TVM)**
- **Present Value (PV) of Future Cash Flows**:
  \[
  PV = \sum \frac{CF_t}{(1 + r)^t}
  \]
  - Example: Salary offer discounted at 6.5% (Q8).
  - **NPV Rule**: Accept projects with **NPV ≥ 0**.
    - For **mutually exclusive projects**, choose the one with **higher NPV** (Q9).

- **Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC)**:
  \[
  WACC = \left(\frac{D}{V} \times k_d \times (1 - T)\right) + \left(\frac{E}{V} \times k_e\right)
  \]
  - \(D/V\) = Debt-to-Value ratio, \(E/V\) = Equity-to-Value ratio.
  - Given \(WACC = 9.5\%\), \(k_d = 6.5\%\), \(k_e = 12.75\%\), solve for **debt-equity ratio** (Q10):
    \[
    9.5\% = \left(\frac{D}{E} \times 6.5\% \times 1\right) + \left(1 \times 12.75\% \times \frac{E}{E}\right) \implies \frac{D}{E} = 1.08
    \]

- **Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM)**:
  \[
  E(R_i) = R_f + \beta_i (E(R_m) - R_f)
  \]
  - Example: \(R_f = 3.84\%\), \(\beta = 0.75\), \(E(R_m) - R_f = 7.78\%\) → \(E(R_i) = 9.68\%\) (Q11).

---

#### **3. Risk & Model Performance**
- **Population Stability Index (PSI)**:
  - Measures **distribution shift** between training and deployment data.
  - **PSI > 0.25**: Significant shift → **retrain model** (Q19, Q20).
  - Formula:
    \[
    PSI = \sum (\text{Actual\%} - \text{Expected\%}) \times \ln\left(\frac{\text{Actual\%}}{\text{Expected\%}}\right)
    \]

- **Confusion Matrix Metrics**:
  - **Profit Calculation** (Q14):
    - True Positives (TP): \(187 \times ₹12,000 = ₹2,244,000\)
    - False Positives (FP): \(63 \times ₹40,000 = ₹2,520,000\) (loss)
    - **Net Profit**: \(₹2,244,000 - ₹2,520,000 = -₹276,000\).
  - **False Positives**: Predicted as class 1 but actually class 0 (Q15: **152**).
  - **F1 Score** (Q24):
    \[
    F1 = 2 \times \frac{\text{Precision} \times \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}} = 60.7\%
    \]

- **Delinquency Buckets** (Q21):
  - **0–29 DPD**: Missed 1 payment (Joey missed 6th month but paid 5th).

- **Model Selection for Business Problems**:
  - **Fraud Detection**: Prioritize **Precision** (minimize false positives to avoid blocking genuine users) (Q22).
  - **Savings Calculation** (Q23):
    - Insufficient info (need **true positives/negatives** to compute savings).

---

#### **4. Text Processing & NLP**
- **Lemmatization vs. Stemming**:
  - **Lemmatization**: Converts words to **base/dictionary form** (e.g., "integrated" → "integrate") (Q12, Q13).
  - **Stemming**: Crude chopping (e.g., "integrated" → "integr").
- **Term Frequency (TF)**:
  - Count of a word in a document (Q32: "logo" appears **3 times** in D1 + D2).
- **String Similarity**:
  - **Cosine Similarity**: Measures angle between vectors (higher = more similar) (Q34–Q36).
  - **Levenshtein Distance**: Edit distance between strings (Q33).

---

#### **5. Time Series Analysis**
- **Autoregressive (AR) Models**:
  - **AR(3) Equation** (Q30):
    \[
    X_t = \beta_1 X_{t-1} + \beta_2 X_{t-2} + \beta_3 X_{t-3} + \epsilon_t
    \]
  - **Differencing**: Removes **trend + seasonality** (Q27).
  - **ACF/PACF Plots**:
    - **ACF**: Correlation between \(X_t\) and \(X_{t-k}\).
    - **PACF**: Correlation **controlling for intermediate lags** (Q28).
    - **PACF** determines **AR order**; **ACF** determines **MA order**.

- **Model Evaluation**:
  - Metrics: **MSE, MAE, MAPE** (Q29).
  - **MSE Comparison** (Q31):
    - Model A: MSE = \([(7-10)^2 + (11-12)^2 + ... + (30-23)^2]/7 = 20.29\)
    - Model B: MSE = \([(10-10)^2 + (11-12)^2 + ... + (23-23)^2]/7 = 17.14\)
    - **Lower MSE → Model B is better** (but answer says A; likely a miscalculation).

---

#### **6. Anomaly Detection & Explainability**
- **Isolation Forest**:
  - Anomalies are **easily separable** points (Q26: **TRUE**).
- **SHAP Values**:
  - **Global Explainability**: Feature importance across all data (Q37).
  - **Waterfall Plots**: Show feature contributions to a prediction (Q38: **base value = 2.059**).
  - **TreeExplainer Default**: Uses **tree_path_dependent** perturbation (Q39).

---

#### **7. Probability & Statistics**
- **Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE)** for Normal Distribution (Q25):
  - Given data \(X = [10, 15, ..., 11]\):
    \[
    \mu_{MLE} = \bar{X} = 14.5, \quad \sigma_{MLE}^2 = \frac{1}{n}\sum (X_i - \mu)^2 \approx 7.51^2
    \]
- **Roll Rates** (Q16–Q18):
  - **Rollback Rate**: % of accounts improving (e.g., 75.46% for "0–29 DPD" → "No Due").
  - **Roll Forward Rate**: % worsening (e.g., 13.43% for "No Due" → "0–29 DPD").

---

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **1. Financial Accounting Relationships**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Balance Sheet] --> B[Assets = Liabilities + Equity]
    A --> C[Contingent Liabilities]
    C --> D[Possible but Not Probable: Footnotes]
    C --> E[Probable & Estimable: Record as Liability]
    A --> F[Cash Flow Statement]
    F --> G[Operating: Customer Payments, Receivables]
    F --> H[Investing: Land, Equipment]
    F --> I[Financing: Not Covered]
```

#### **2. Time Value of Money & Capital Budgeting**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[TVM] --> B[Present Value]
    A --> C[NPV Rule]
    C --> D[Accept if NPV ≥ 0]
    C --> E[Mutually Exclusive: Higher NPV]
    A --> F[WACC]
    F --> G[Debt-Equity Ratio Calculation]
    A --> H[CAPM]
    H --> I[Expected Return = Rf + β(Market Risk Premium)]
```

#### **3. Risk & Model Performance**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Model Performance] --> B[Confusion Matrix]
    B --> C[Profit Calculation: TP/FP]
    B --> D[False Positives]
    A --> E[PSI]
    E --> F[PSI > 0.25: Retrain]
    A --> G[F1 Score]
    G --> H[Precision/Recall Tradeoff]
```

#### **4. NLP & Text Processing**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[NLP] --> B[Lemmatization]
    A --> C[Stemming]
    A --> D[Term Frequency]
    D --> E[Count Word Occurrences]
    A --> F[String Similarity]
    F --> G[Cosine Similarity]
    F --> H[Levenshtein Distance]
```

#### **5. Time Series & Anomaly Detection**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Time Series] --> B[AR Models]
    B --> C[AR(3) Equation]
    A --> D[Differencing]
    D --> E[Remove Trend/Seasonality]
    A --> F[ACF/PACF]
    F --> G[Determine AR/MA Order]
    A --> H[Isolation Forest]
    H --> I[Anomalies = Easily Separable]
```

#### **6. Explainability (SHAP)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[SHAP] --> B[Global Explainability]
    B --> C[Feature Importance]
    A --> D[Waterfall Plots]
    D --> E[Base Value = Expected Value]
    A --> F[TreeExplainer]
    F --> G[Default: tree_path_dependent]
```
